solution_line_template: Tara has to make a ${laptop_cost} x {down_payment_percentage_numerator}/{down_payment_percentage_denominator} = $<<{laptop_cost}*{down_payment_percentage_numerator}/{down_payment_percentage_denominator}={required_down_payment}>>{required_down_payment} down payment.

Since Tara wants to pay ${additional_down_payment} more for the down payment, her total down payment will be ${required_down_payment} + ${additional_down_payment} = $<<{required_down_payment}+{additional_down_payment}={total_down_payment}>>{total_down_payment}.
So her remaining balance payable over a year is ${laptop_cost} - ${total_down_payment} = $<<{laptop_cost}-{total_down_payment}={remaining_balance}>>{remaining_balance}.
Tara has to make a monthly payment of ${remaining_balance}/year / {months_per_year} months/year = $<<{remaining_balance}/{months_per_year}={monthly_payment}>>{monthly_payment}/month.
The total cost of her payments for {months_paid} months is ${monthly_payment}/month x {months_paid} months = $<<{monthly_payment}*{months_paid}={total_paid_in_4_months}>>{total_paid_in_4_months}.
Therefore, Tara's balance after {months_paid} months is ${remaining_balance} - ${total_paid_in_4_months} = $<<{remaining_balance}-{total_paid_in_4_months}={answer}>>{answer}.
